help9.value: Copyright Project PhET and the Univerisity of Colorado at Boulder.

help8.value: Unlike Runge-Kutta, the Verlet algorithm conserves energy in oscillatory systems,  producing stable orbits. As with any fixed-timestep algorithm, Verlet produces unphysical results when bodies get too close and the resulting accelerations are too large. To prevent this, bodies that get too close are fused in a momentum-conserving collision.

help6.value: This simulation uses a fixed-timestep velocity-Verlet algorithm to integrate trajectories:

help5.value: When System Centered is checked,  the system's center-of-mass motion is removed.

help4.value: For current position and velocity, press Stop and mouse over the body.

help3.value: Keep masses less than a few thousand or risk strange results.

help2.value: Distances, masses, and times are in arbitrary units.  Invent your own!

help1.value: Make your own solar system by dragging bodies and the V symbol (V for velocity) \nor by typing into the Initial Settings table.
